verses.text: But a certain man named Ananias, with Sapphira his wife, sold a piece of property,
verses.comment: This story immediately follows the generosity of Barnabas (Acts 4:36-37), showing a sharp contrast in motives regarding communal charity. This passage introduces the theme of integrity and judgment in the early Christian community.

verses.text: and with his wife's knowledge, he kept back part of the money for himself, and brought only a part and laid it at the apostles’ feet.
verses.comment: The act of laying money at the apostles' feet signifies trust in apostolic authority and the early practice of unified resource-sharing.

verses.text: But Peter said, 'Ananias, why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and to keep back for yourself part of the money for the land?'
verses.comment: Peter's discernment shows a charism given to him, echoing Christ’s warning about Satan (Luke 22:31). Lying to the Holy Spirit is equated with lying to God, underscoring the divinity of the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: 'While it remained unsold, did it not remain your own? And after it was sold, was it not under your control? Why did you plan this thing in your heart? You have not lied to men, but to God.'
verses.comment: Peter clarifies the issue is not about mandatory giving but hypocrisy and deceit. This demonstrates the apostolic role in guarding the spiritual health of the community.

verses.text: When Ananias heard these words, he fell down and died. And great fear came on all who heard about it.
verses.comment: Sudden death recalls Old Testament judgments for profaning holy things. This event marks the seriousness of sin within the Church as the ‘new temple’ (see 1 Cor. 3:17).

verses.text: The young men arose, wrapped him up, and carried him out and buried him.
verses.comment: Immediate burial was a sign of serious divine judgment (Deut. 21:22-23). This act also emphasizes order and discipline within the early community.

verses.text: After about three hours his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.
verses.comment: The time interval demonstrates both the seriousness and impartiality of the judgment.

verses.text: Peter said to her, 'Tell me, did you sell the land for this price?' She said, 'Yes, for that much.'
verses.comment: Peter, in an act of pastoral authority, invites Sapphira to confess. The unrepentant lie repeats the sin.

verses.text: Then Peter said to her, 'How is it that you have agreed together to test the Spirit of the Lord? Behold, the feet of those who buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out as well.'
verses.comment: ‘Testing the Spirit’ alludes to Israel testing God in the wilderness. It reinforces the seriousness of rebellion inside the Church.

verses.text: Immediately, she fell down at his feet and died. When the young men came in, they found her dead, and they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
verses.comment: Both were judged the same way for the same act—emphasizing equal accountability before God within the Church.

verses.text: And great fear came upon the whole church, and upon all who heard these things.
verses.comment: The awe and reverence experienced by the community shows the seriousness of holiness and discipline in the one Church.

verses.text: Now many signs and wonders were done among the people by the hands of the apostles. And they were all together in Solomon’s Portico.
verses.comment: The apostles continue the ministry of Jesus through miracles, confirming their divine authority and the visible unity of the Church.

verses.text: None of the rest dared join them, but the people held them in high esteem.
verses.comment: The community's awe shows both fear and deep respect for the apostolic leaders.

verses.text: And more than ever believers were added to the Lord, multitudes of both men and women.
verses.comment: The Spirit continues to grow the Church. Note the inclusion of both men and women, echoing the openness of Christ’s ministry.

verses.text: So they even carried the sick out into the streets and laid them on beds and mats, so that as Peter came by, at least his shadow might fall on some of them.
verses.comment: The healing power associated with Peter, even his shadow, shows God working miraculously through chosen leaders, reinforcing the unique authority granted to key apostles.

verses.text: And crowds gathered from the towns around Jerusalem, bringing the sick and those troubled by unclean spirits, and they were all healed.
verses.comment: Here, apostolic healing, by the Spirit, fulfills Christ’s commission and displays the tangible means of grace present in the visible community.

verses.text: But the high priest rose up, and all who were with him, that is, the party of the Sadducees, and they were filled with jealousy.
verses.comment: Jealousy of the religious authorities contrasts with the growth of the true community guided by the Spirit.

verses.text: And they arrested the apostles and put them in the public prison.
verses.comment: Opposition intensifies. Just as Jesus was arrested, His followers too face persecution.

verses.text: But during the night an angel of the Lord opened the prison doors and brought them out, and said,
verses.comment: Divine intervention recalls earlier rescues (Dan. 3) and authenticates the apostles’ mission.

verses.text: 'Go and stand in the temple and speak to the people all the words of this Life.'
verses.comment: 'Words of this Life' refers to the fullness of life offered through Christ in His Church.

verses.text: And when they heard this, they entered the temple at daybreak and began to teach. Now when the high priest and those with him came, they called the council together and all the elders of the people, and sent to the prison to have them brought.
verses.comment: The courage of the apostles shows their obedience to God’s word over human threats (see Acts 4:19).

verses.text: But when the officers came, they did not find them in the prison, and they returned and reported,
verses.comment: The miraculous escape confuses the authorities, demonstrating God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: 'We found the prison securely locked and the guards standing at the doors, but when we opened them, we found no one inside.'
verses.comment: The supernatural nature of the event is undeniable; no ordinary explanation suffices.

verses.text: Now when the captain of the temple and the chief priests heard these words, they were greatly perplexed about them, wondering what this could come to.
verses.comment: The authorities’ confusion contrasts with the clarity and mission of the apostles.

verses.text: And someone came and told them, 'Look, the men whom you put in prison are standing in the temple and teaching the people!'
verses.comment: God’s messengers cannot be silenced. The teaching continues in the face of threats.

verses.text: Then the captain went with the officers and brought them, but not by force, for they were afraid of being stoned by the people.
verses.comment: Public opinion restrains the authorities, revealing the influence of the apostles within the community.

verses.text: When they had brought them, they set them before the council. And the high priest questioned them,
verses.comment: This is the Sanhedrin—the highest Jewish authority—mirroring Jesus’ trial.

verses.text: 'We strictly charged you not to teach in this name. Yet, look, you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching, and you intend to bring this man’s blood upon us.'
verses.comment: The charge of teaching 'in this name' (Jesus) shows the centrality and power of Christ’s name in the apostolic faith.

verses.text: But Peter and the apostles answered, 'We must obey God rather than men.'
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s authority takes precedence—an early doctrine of divine-command ethics.

verses.text: 'The God of our fathers raised Jesus, whom you killed by hanging him on a tree.'
verses.comment: 'Hanging on a tree' is a scriptural sign of being cursed (Deut. 21:22-23), yet God overturns this by raising Jesus, revealing Him as the Messiah.

verses.text: 'God exalted Him at His right hand as Leader and Savior, to give repentance to Israel and forgiveness of sins.'
verses.comment: Christ’s exaltation fulfills Psalm 110. Repentance and forgiveness of sins are here connected to His authority, a theme reflected in sacramental confession later on.

verses.text: 'And we are witnesses of these things, and so is the Holy Spirit, whom God has given to those who obey Him.'
verses.comment: Apostolic witness, together with the Holy Spirit, affirms the essential role of tradition and ongoing leadership.

verses.text: When they heard this, they were enraged and wanted to kill them.
verses.comment: This response echoes the violent opposition Jesus Himself faced; the disciples share in His suffering.

verses.text: But a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law, held in honor by all the people, stood up in the council and ordered the apostles to be put outside for a little while.
verses.comment: Gamaliel, Paul’s teacher, is a voice of wisdom and moderation in the council.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'Men of Israel, take care what you are about to do with these men.'
verses.comment: Gamaliel’s cautious approach brings a moment of reason.

verses.text: 'For before these days Theudas rose up, claiming to be somebody, and a number of men, about four hundred, joined him; he was killed, and all those who followed him were dispersed and came to nothing.'
verses.comment: Historical references ground the drama in real events, warning against rash action.

verses.text: 'After him Judas the Galilean arose in the days of the census and drew away some of the people after him; he also perished, and all who followed him were scattered.'
verses.comment: Gamaliel’s examples serve to show that human inventions will fail, but those from God will endure.

verses.text: 'So in the present case I tell you, keep away from these men and let them alone, for if this plan or undertaking is of man, it will fail;'
verses.comment: True works of God cannot be overthrown by human means. This principle continues to guide Church history.

verses.text: 'but if it is from God, you will not be able to overthrow them. You might even be found opposing God!' So they took his advice.
verses.comment: Gamaliel’s logic shows God’s sovereignty. The survival and expansion of the Church strongly suggest God’s ongoing work through it.

verses.text: And when they had called in the apostles, they beat them and charged them not to speak in the name of Jesus, and let them go.
verses.comment: Even after persecution, the apostles are released, highlighting steadfastness under suffering and obedience to God above all.

verses.text: Then they departed from the council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer dishonor for the name.
verses.comment: Suffering for Christ is seen as a privilege. It echoes Jesus' words about persecution for His name and previews the tradition of joyful witness under trial.

verses.text: And every day, in the temple and from house to house, they did not cease teaching and proclaiming Jesus as the Christ.
verses.comment: The unbroken pattern of public and private teaching reveals the mission of the Church: to announce Jesus as Messiah continually, everywhere, and to form believers in the faith throughout households and public worship.
